bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 30, 1922

div1.p: Connor discusses field work and a difficult case, in San Cristobal. Connor is worried that yellow fever's demise in Peru will be announced too soon.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 30, 1922

My dear Doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
I have your letter of May 15th
with enclosures- Am returning copy of letter
to Caldwell- The copy you sent me some-
time ago came OK. The San Cristobal
case was in all probability not a case-
altho - Caldwell maintains it was-

I have just completed an inspection
with Caldwell of the Papalaupan Valley and come
with the impression that Tuxtepec had been the
endemic center here in recent years and will
so report to Dr. White. The early work of this
campaign failed in that it did not make an
epidemiological survey - had this been - the
area would be clean long ago - as it is I believe
it is clean but am not justified in making
a positive statement- The next few months will
tell the tale. Caldwell is now sweeping the
Valley and I hope will do it at five times,
from Alvarado to Tuxtepec, then to Ojetelan
after which comes the mountains.

I think I wrote you that we are
stopping work in Tampico area
on July 1st - my own thoughts are
that this can be safely done and
Dr. White agrees with me-

Your principle of the “failure of the human
host” has made it possible to
hold out encouragement for success
in this world campaign, and to those
workers in the y.f. field who understand what
is meant by “failure of the human host” it has
been of the greatest aid in shaping their work.
To much credit can not be given you for
formulating this principal.

Dr. Rose writes that the work in Peru will
close July 1st - but I hope the Board will not
make an announcement that y. f. is out
but rather announce that the last case occured
on such and such a date- The Salvador
experience was costly and was arrived at
on without a careful study of conditions
there. The African trip may take place
sometime this year, a laboratory man
is still lacking - when conditions here permit
the expidetion could go forward with one
laboratory man and the other come out
when trained- Dr. Rose seems very well impressed

with your recommendation of Walcott and he
will probably be made a member-

We look for Dr. White here about the middle
of June-
div1.closer:
With sincere good wishes to you and
your- M E Connor.
P. S. Pasconcellos says that “Faetida” grows in this county. He sent
us some to Merida, but it seemingly died on the way the
water in which it was sent was became putrid- It may be
OK or for field work but more work must be done before it
can be recommended for house receptacles-
MEC
